posts.text:
Train diffusion LLMs on your low cardinality high quality data, then use those to generate higher quality synthetic prose to train the transformers on.

arxiv.org/abs/2507.15857

reply_context.text: Actually for quality content main issue: there is so few and transformers has a high data inertia (and don’t like abusive repetitions either: that’s actual model collapse). So we need to "replay" the data somewhat, hence distant writing.

posts.text: re: poetry and prose, I think a contributing factor is that most of the public content is trash like HS writing and fanfics, and the quality content is expensive and consequently not utilized and so not available to learn from.

reply_context.text:
I'd posit that synthetic data is primarily useful for:
* generating data for learning to solve inverse problems
  -> provide LLM a context to generate from, then try to predict context from generated output
* data augmentation as translation/morphism
  -> given text, rewrite as (style1, style2, ..)

Diffusion training continues to extract value from the data beyond the irreducible loss achievable by the discrete causal objective. It renders post-training "polishing" unnecessary (insofar as that post-training is geared towards additional generalized performance improvement)

reply_context.text: It (seems to) resolve the need for RL to begin with. The reason post-training is needed is because the discretized (tokenized) causal prediction objective is bounded to a strictly higher irreducible loss. It converges faster than diffusion training, but as a consequence it leaves value on the table.

reply_context.text:
The benefits of cloud infra aren't just that you pay-what you use and don't need to maintain physical hardware. You also get the benefit of backend expertise dedicated to operating your infra. This manifests directly as time and cost savings for long distributed jobs on CRWV compute.

6/

posts.text:

reply_context.text:
Large distributed training jobs are extremely complex systems with a lot of moving parts. It's easy to mistakenly make sub-optimal decisions that result in cost differences of thousands or millions of $$.

One of the main benefits of using cloud clusters is offloading a lot of these decisions. 

5/

posts.text:

* Poor temperature management can result in reduced performance and higher likelihood of device failure
* Lazy configuration decisions can result in slower network communication, causing longer step times
* Container build decisions can reduce performance of code and recovery

4/

reply_context.text:
A GPU XYYY from one cloud provider is not the same as GPU XYYY from another. The same GPU from different manufacturers can have significantly different performance. Even from the same manufacturer, cluster and hardware configuration decisions can result in significant impacts to performance.

3/

reply_context.text:
All cloud infra is not the same. When running a long, complex, distributed job, micro-optimizations can make a huge difference. Things like:
* network tuned for AI communication
* automated node validation and replacement to ensure all nodes available for use are healthy and stable
